did.unittitle: Ken Rush photographs of the Smith-9th Streets subway station
did.abstract: Six Polaroids mounted on three sheets of black paper depicting the interior of the Smith-9th Streets subway station, including shots of the original wooden escalator, taken in the 1970s by painter Ken Rush in preparation for the painting Smith-9th Streets.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This small collection is housed in a single folder with no particular arrangement.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Ken Rush is a painter who balances his time between Brooklyn and Vermont. He has had numerous solo exhibitions since 1985. His work is in the permanent public collections of the 9/11 Memorial and Museum, the Center for Brooklyn History, The Bennington Museum, and the The SUArt Galleries. Ken has lived in Brooklyn since 1971, and was the upper school visual arts and art history teacher at Packer Collegiate Institute in Brooklyn Heights from 1978 to 2015. He is a long term resident of Carroll Gardens where he continues his studio practice.

Smith-9th Streets in one of a dozen subway station paintings created by Rush in 1973 and 1974. It depicts the Smith–Ninth Streets elevated subway platform looking south towards Brooklyn and the Verrazano Bridge.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: These photographs were taken in preparation for the painting "Smith-9th Streets," held in the Center for Brooklyn History Art and Artifact collection (object ID 2019.010.1).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Six Polaroids mounted on three sheets of black paper depicting the interior of the Smith-9th Streets subway station, including shots of the original wooden escalator, taken in the 1970s by Ken Rush. These photographs were taken in preparation for the painting "Smith-9th Streets," one of a dozen subway station paintings created by Rush in 1973 and 1974. It depicts the Smith–Ninth Streets elevated subway platform looking south towards Brooklyn and the Verrazano Bridge.
